entity1.name: Sleep
entity1.description: A stage of sleep characterized by the absence of rapid eye movements, relatively low brain activity, and muscle tone.;;;A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced consciousness and metabolic activity.;;;A fundamental biological process essential for human health and well-being.;;;A stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movements, low muscle tone throughout the body, and vivid dreams.;;;A stage of sleep characterized by rapid movements of the eyes, increased respiration rate, and greater dreaming.;;;The progression of sleep stages that occurs repeatedly throughout a period of sleep, typically lasting about 90 minutes in humans.;;;A naturally recurring state characterized by reduced or absent consciousness, relatively suspended sensory activity, and inactivity of nearly all voluntary muscles.;;;A stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movement and increased brain activity, during which most dreaming occurs.;;;A stage of sleep characterized by the absence of rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, and dreaming.;;;Distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, each characterized by specific brain wave activity and physiological changes.;;;Distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, each characterized by specific brain wave patterns and physiological changes.;;;A naturally recurring state of rest characterized by altered consciousness, relatively inhibited sensory activity, and reduced muscle activity.;;;An internal process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.;;;A stage of sleep marked by rapid eye movements, high brain activity, and vivid dreaming.;;;A stage of deep sleep that is divided into several stages, each with distinct brain wave patterns and physiological characteristics.;;;The distinct phases that occur during the sleep cycle, typically divided into non-rapid eye movement (NREM) and rapid eye movement (REM) stages.;;;An internal biological process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.;;;The set of life-sustaining chemical reactions in organisms, including anabolism (building molecules) and catabolism (breaking down molecules).;;;A metaphorical term for the circadian rhythm, which helps regulate various biological processes including sleep and wakefulness.;;;The natural pattern of sleeping and waking over a 24-hour period, also known as the circadian rhythm.;;;A characteristic of certain sleep stages, particularly REM sleep, where the eyes move quickly in various directions.;;;The functions and activities that occur within living organisms to maintain life, including but not limited to metabolism, homeostasis, and cell signaling.
entity1.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep15;;;The Science Behind Sleep20;;;The Science Behind Sleep3;;;The Science Behind Sleep5;;;The Science Behind Sleep6;;;The Science Behind Sleep11;;;The Science Behind Sleep14;;;The Science Behind Sleep4;;;The Science Behind Sleep25;;;The Science Behind Sleep17;;;The Science Behind Sleep21;;;The Science Behind Sleep13;;;The Science Behind Sleep23;;;The Science Behind Sleep12;;;The Science Behind Sleep26;;;The Science Behind Sleep1;;;The Science Behind Sleep10

entity2.name: Human Health
entity2.description: A state of being comfortable, healthy, and happy, which can be enhanced by sufficient sleep.;;;A state of being comfortable, healthy, or happy.;;;The sufficient duration and quality of sleep necessary to maintain physical and mental well-being.;;;The condition of being free from illness or injury; a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being.;;;The state of being free from illness or injury, which is supported by adequate sleep.
entity2.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep3;;;The Science Behind Sleep1;;;The Science Behind Sleep25

entity6.name: factors that influence sleep
entity6.description: Various internal and external elements that can affect the quality and quantity of sleep, such as age, health conditions, environment, and lifestyle choices.

entity14.name: N1
entity14.description: The lightest stage of sleep where individuals may experience drifting in and out of consciousness.;;;A specific stage of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep characterized by a decrease in body temperature and heart rate, as well as the onset of sleep spindles and K-complexes.;;;The first stage of non-REM sleep, also known as light sleep, where the body begins to relax and slow down.;;;The third stage of non-REM sleep, also known as deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, where the body undergoes physical restoration.;;;A stage of sleep characterized by slow brain waves, also known as slow-wave sleep.;;;The second stage of non-REM sleep, characterized by further slowing of brain waves and deeper relaxation.
entity14.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep9;;;The Science Behind Sleep6;;;The Science Behind Sleep7;;;The Science Behind Sleep8

entity19.name: sleep spindles
entity19.description: Brief bursts of brain activity that occur during stage 2 (N2) of non-rapid eye movement sleep, typically lasting for about half a second to two seconds.

entity20.name: K-complexes
entity20.description: A high-amplitude delta wave that occurs during stage 2 (N2) of non-rapid eye movement sleep, often in response to external stimuli or internal events.

entity22.name: slow-wave sleep
entity22.description: The deepest stage of non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep, associated with restorative processes in the body.

entity25.name: Increased brain activity
entity25.description: Refers to heightened levels of neural activity in the brain, often observed during specific states such as REM sleep or under certain stimuli.

entity26.name: Muscle paralysis
entity26.description: A state where muscles are unable to move, commonly occurring during REM sleep to prevent the acting out of dreams.

entity28.name: memory consolidation
entity28.description: The mental processes involved in acquiring knowledge and understanding through thought, experience, and the senses.;;;The process by which new information is encoded and stabilized in the brain for long-term storage.
entity28.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep23;;;The Science Behind Sleep12

entity29.name: emotional processing
entity29.description: The cognitive and physiological processes that occur when an individual perceives, interprets, and responds to emotional stimuli.

entity34.name: neurotransmitters
entity34.description: A neurotransmitter involved in regulating mood, appetite, and sleep.;;;Endogenous chemicals that transmit signals across a synapse from one neuron to another 'target' neuron or other cells, such as muscles or glands.;;;A group of nerve cells that communicate with each other using chemical messengers called neurotransmitters.
entity34.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep14;;;The Science Behind Sleep17;;;The Science Behind Sleep18

entity37.name: suprachiasmatic nucleus
entity37.description: A small region in the brain that acts as the body's master clock, regulating circadian rhythms.

entity38.name: brain
entity38.description: The central organ of the nervous system, responsible for controlling and coordinating bodily functions and activities.

entity39.name: melatonin
entity39.description: A hormone produced by the pineal gland that regulates sleep-wake cycles.
entity39.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep16;;;The Science Behind Sleep20

entity41.name: adenosine
entity41.description: A chemical that promotes sleep by binding to receptors in the brain, leading to drowsiness.

entity43.name: dopamine
entity43.description: A neurotransmitter associated with pleasure, reward, and regulation of movement and emotional responses.

entity45.name: sleep disorders
entity45.description: A range of conditions characterized by disturbances in the amount, quality, or timing of sleep.;;;A prolonged lack of adequate sleep that can lead to various health issues.;;;A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep.;;;A common sleep disorder where individuals have trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or both.
entity45.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep24;;;The Science Behind Sleep18

entity47.name: narcolepsy
entity47.description: A chronic neurological disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep.

entity49.name: light exposure
entity49.description: The amount of light that a person is exposed to, which can affect various biological processes including sleep.

entity50.name: noise
entity50.description: Sound levels in the environment that can disturb or enhance sleep quality depending on their intensity and nature.;;;A disturbance that can affect the quality of sleep.
entity50.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep19;;;The Science Behind Sleep21

entity51.name: temperature
entity51.description: The degree of hotness or coldness in an environment, which can impact sleep quality.;;;The degree of hotness or coldness in the sleeping environment, which can significantly affect comfort and sleep quality.
entity51.chunkid: The Science Behind Sleep19;;;The Science Behind Sleep21

entity52.name: lifestyle choices
entity52.description: Personal habits and decisions that individuals make, such as diet, exercise, and bedtime routines, which can influence sleep patterns and quality.

entity59.name: immune function
entity59.description: The body's ability to defend against pathogens and other foreign substances through the immune system.

entity63.name: obesity
entity63.description: A medical condition characterized by excessive body fat accumulation, which may adversely affect health.

entity64.name: diabetes
entity64.description: A group of metabolic disorders characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period.

entity65.name: cardiovascular disease
entity65.description: A class of diseases that involve the heart or blood vessels, including conditions such as coronary artery disease and hypertension.

entity66.name: mental health disorders
entity66.description: A range of conditions affecting a person's thinking, feeling, or mood, which may be characterized by significant impairment in daily functioning.
